message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Tetanus toxoid should be given to patients who are at risk of tetanus, regardless of their medication use or age. However, patients taking glucocorticoids or with rheumatoid arthritis may have a reduced response to the vaccine, which is why immunoglobulin is added to provide immediate protection until their own antibodies can develop. Option B is the correct answer as it explains the rationale behind administering both tetanus toxoid and immunoglobulin. Option A is incorrect as tetanus toxoid should still be administered, even if the patient is taking glucocorticoids. Option C is incorrect as there is no age limit for receiving tetanus prophylaxis. Option D is incorrect as the duration of protection provided by immunoglobulin varies and depends on the dose administered.

We refer to CDC guidelines on tetanus prophylaxis for help. Methylprednisolone does not affect the patient's immune response to tetanus toxoid, so it is still reasonable to administer tetanus toxoid. However, because the wound is contaminated and the patient's vaccination history is uncertain, both tetanus toxoid and immunoglobulin should be given. Immunoglobulin provides immediate passive immunity until the patient's own antibodies develop, but the protection is short-lived (approximately 2-4 weeks). Therefore, the patient will still need the tetanus toxoid vaccine to induce active immunity and provide long-term protection. Option A is incorrect because oral glucocorticoids do not interfere with the immune response to tetanus toxoid. Option C is incorrect because there is no upper age limit for tetanus toxoid administration. Option D is incorrect because the duration of protection provided by immunoglobulin is shorter than 4 months.

We refer to UpToDate for help. Option A is incorrect because although glucocorticoids can suppress the immune system, they do not completely prevent the development of immune response to vaccines. Option B is correct; administering both tetanus toxoid and immunoglobulin will provide immediate protection against tetanus infection while the patient's own immune system takes time to produce antibodies. Option C is incorrect because age alone is not a contraindication for tetanus toxoid administration. Option D is incorrect because immunoglobulin administration provides temporary immunity, not constant levels of antibodies for more than 4 months.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Patients taking oral glucocorticoids may have decreased immune response to vaccines, but the tetanus toxoid is still recommended as it can still induce some level of immunity. The immunoglobulin administration is given to immediately provide anti-tetanus toxin antibodies while waiting for the patient’s own immunity to develop. Tetanus toxoid should be given to all patients regardless of their age. The immunoglobulin administration can provide constant levels of antibodies for about 2-3 weeks.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Patients on oral glucocorticoids may have a decreased immune response to tetanus toxoid, but it is still recommended to administer the vaccine. The immunoglobulin administration provides immediate passive immunity until the patient’s own immune system can produce sufficient active immunity. Tetanus toxoid can be given to patients over the age of 60 years, and immunoglobulin administration provides constant levels of antibodies for only a few weeks, not months. Therefore, the correct answer is (B).

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Tetanus prophylaxis is necessary in this patient as her wound is contaminated and she cannot recall her vaccination history. The patient’s glucocorticoid use does not contraindicate the administration of tetanus toxoid. The immunoglobulin is given to provide immediate passive immunity until the patient’s own antibodies start to generate. The effects of immunoglobulin administration last between 2 to 4 weeks.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Patients taking glucocorticoids can still receive tetanus toxoid, but it may be less effective. It is recommended to administer both tetanus toxoid and immunoglobulin for contaminated wounds. Immunoglobulin provides immediate protection while the patient’s own antibodies develop. Age over 60 does not impact the effectiveness of tetanus toxoid. Immunoglobulin levels usually decline after several weeks, not months. Therefore, option B is correct.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Patients who take oral glucocorticoids may have an impaired immune response to tetanus toxoid rendering them at higher risk for tetanus infection. Tetanus toxoid should still be administered to stimulate an immune response. The immunoglobulin administration will provide immediate passive immunity until the patient’s own immune response has a chance to produce antibodies. Option C is incorrect as the tetanus vaccine is recommended for all adults regardless of age. Option D is incorrect as the immunoglobulin administration provides temporary passive immunity and the duration of this immunity is limited to weeks.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Patients with immunosuppressive therapy may show poor or no response to tetanus toxoid, but it is still recommended to administer both tetanus toxoid and immunoglobulin after wound treatment. Option B is correct, as the immunoglobulin administration will provide immediate passive immunity until the patient’s own antibodies start to develop in response to the tetanus toxoid. Option C is incorrect as age is not a contraindication for tetanus toxoid administration, and Option D is incorrect as the effects of immunoglobulin administration typically last only a few weeks, not months.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Tetanus toxoid should still be administered regardless of the patient’s steroid intake as it will still provide some level of protection. The immunoglobulin administration will provide immediate protection until the patient's own immune system can produce antibodies. The administration of tetanus toxoid is still recommended for patients above 60 years old. The immunoglobulin administration will provide constant levels of antibodies for up to 3 weeks, not 4 months.
